historicalName: Ponte dei Dai in Sestiere Cannaregio
englishName: Bridge of the Dai in Cannaregio District
historicalDescription: A bridge in the Cannaregio sestiere, near the Church of Santa Maria dei Miracoli. The area was known for its artisan workshops and proximity to the Jewish Ghetto.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: This dock takes its name from the adjacent Ponte dei Dai (Bridge of Dice) in Cannaregio. The area was historically associated with gambling activities, particularly dice games, which were popular despite periodic attempts by Venetian authorities to regulate them. Merchants and gondoliers would gather here, making it a bustling commercial landing point.

Located near Ponte dei Dai, this dock served as a gathering point for professional gamblers and nobles seeking entertainment in the 16th century. The name reflects the gambling culture that flourished in this part of Cannaregio, where wealthy Venetians and visitors would arrive by boat to participate in games of chance in nearby establishments.

This dock earned its name from the betting activities that took place in the vicinity of Ponte dei Dai. During the Renaissance, it was common for Venetian nobles and merchants to place wagers on various events, from regattas to political outcomes. This fondamenta would have served local residents and visitors coming to engage in both legitimate and illicit betting.

This dock served the textile workers who lived and worked in this section of Cannaregio during the 15th-16th centuries. Textile production was a major industry in Venice, and many skilled weavers established workshops in this area. The dock would have been used for receiving raw materials and shipping finished textiles, providing an important economic function for the local artisan community.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the blacksmith workshops that were historically located near this bridge in the Cannaregio district. These artisans crafted ironwork for ships, buildings, and decorative elements throughout Venice.

This bridge near Ponte dei Dai got its name from the small decorative spires visible from this vantage point. While the more famous Ponte delle Guglie has larger ornamental elements, this smaller bridge offered views of the minor spires of nearby churches.

connection.englishName: Bridge of the Three Minor Arches
connection.historicalDescription: A smaller counterpart to the famous Ponte dei Tre Archi in Cannaregio, this bridge featured three modest arches in its design. It served as an important crossing point for residents of this working-class neighborhood.

Named for its proximity to a charitable institution established in the 16th century. The Scuola della Misericordia was one of Venice's confraternities dedicated to acts of mercy and charity in the Cannaregio district.

This bridge connected to an area with small shipyards (squeri) where boats and gondolas were built and repaired. The Cannaregio canal provided access for these small-scale maritime construction activities essential to Venetian daily life.

Named for the small traditional Venetian snacks (cichetti) sold at taverns near this bridge. These establishments were popular gathering spots for working-class Venetians in the Cannaregio district after their daily labors.

connection.englishName: Bridge of the Small Madonna of the Garden
connection.historicalDescription: Located on a minor canal route leading toward the famous Madonna dell'Orto church in Cannaregio. This bridge served pilgrims and parishioners accessing one of Venice's most important religious sites since the 14th century.

Named for the fishermen and lagoon workers who traversed this bridge daily. Many residents of this area of Cannaregio made their living from the surrounding lagoon, harvesting fish, shellfish, and salt.

This bridge in Cannaregio connected to warehouses where hemp was stored for rope-making, an essential industry for the maritime Republic. The hemp was processed into ropes for Venice's vast fleet of trading and naval vessels.

Named for the modest dwellings (casoncini) that characterized this working-class area of Cannaregio near Ponte dei Dai. These simple structures housed many of the craftspeople, laborers, and merchants who kept Venice functioning.

While most glassmaking was concentrated on Murano, this bridge in Cannaregio connected to workshops of smaller glassmakers who created more affordable pieces for everyday use, distinguishing them from the master craftsmen of Murano.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the dice games that were popular in this area of Cannaregio during the Renaissance. The nearby Ponte dei Dai (Bridge of Dice) was a known gathering spot for gamblers.

This fondamenta (walkway along a canal) was frequented by gamblers who would congregate near Ponte dei Dai for games of chance, particularly popular among merchants and sailors in this area of Cannaregio.

A former canal that was filled in (rio terà) and named after the goddess of fortune. The name references the gambling activities that took place near Ponte dei Dai, where fortunes could be won or lost on a throw of dice.
A street marking an important boundary within Cannaregio, one of Venice's six sestieri (districts). It served as a main thoroughfare connected to the Ponte dei Dai area.

A covered passageway where money changers and informal bankers would set up to facilitate gambling activities near Ponte dei Dai, exchanging different currencies for local gamblers and visiting merchants.

Named after the noble Contarini family who owned properties in this part of Cannaregio. The Contarini were one of Venice's most powerful nobili families, producing eight Doges between the 11th and 17th centuries.

This fondamenta leads toward the Ghetto Vecchio (Old Ghetto), established in 1516 in Cannaregio as the world's first ghetto where Jewish residents were required to live. It connected the Jewish quarter with the gambling area of Ponte dei Dai.
Named after the risk-takers who frequented the gambling establishments near Ponte dei Dai. These azzardosi (risk-takers) would often stake large sums on games of chance.

A commercial street where German merchants conducted business. Cannaregio hosted many foreign merchants, and this area near Ponte dei Dai saw significant trade activity from German-speaking territories.

Named for the betting activities that took place in this area of Cannaregio. Near Ponte dei Dai, various forms of gambling including betting on outcomes of events were common, despite periodic attempts by authorities to control such activities.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Grisoni Family
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A paved street (salizada) named after the Grisoni, a family of Venetian merchants who lived in Cannaregio. They likely had properties near Ponte dei Dai and contributed to paving this street, which was considered a mark of influence.
A small square where locals would gather to try their luck at games of chance. Its proximity to Ponte dei Dai made it a natural extension of the gambling activities for which the bridge was named.
Named after the craftsmen who made bags and pouches. In Cannaregio near Ponte dei Dai, these artisans would have produced the small pouches used by gamblers to hold their coins and dice.

A former canal that was filled in and named after the tabarro, a traditional Venetian cloak. Gamblers at Ponte dei Dai often wore these cloaks to conceal their identities or their wealth while engaged in games of chance.
Named for the numerous taverns that lined this street near Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio. These establishments served wine and food to gamblers and provided additional spaces for games of chance.

A covered passageway named after 'il punto' (the point), a term used in dice games to refer to the score. Located near Ponte dei Dai, this passage might have contained small shops catering to gamblers.
Named after the lucky number seven in dice games. This fondamenta near Ponte dei Dai would have been lined with buildings where gamblers gathered, hoping to roll the fortuitous seven.
Named after the helmsmen who navigated Venetian ships. Many sailors, including timonieri, would frequent the gambling areas near Ponte dei Dai during their shore leave in this part of Cannaregio.

A commercial street where playing card makers had their workshops. Although Ponte dei Dai was primarily associated with dice, card games were also popular, and artisans in this area of Cannaregio produced playing cards for gamblers.

Named for the illicit activities that sometimes took place here. Despite periodic prohibitions against gambling by Venetian authorities, games continued in this area near Ponte dei Dai, sometimes in secret locations along this street.

Named after the brokers who facilitated various transactions. In the Ponte dei Dai area of Cannaregio, these sensali might have arranged high-stakes games or acted as intermediaries for wealthy gamblers who preferred to remain anonymous.

Named after a popular card game in Renaissance Venice. Near Ponte dei Dai, this street would have contained establishments where the game of zecchinetta was played, a gambling activity that used a special deck of cards.
A former canal that was filled in and named after the card game 'trentuno' (thirty-one), which was popular among gamblers in this area of Cannaregio near Ponte dei Dai.

Named for the late-night gamblers who frequented this area. Gambling activities near Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio would often continue throughout the night, with dedicated players known as 'notturni' pursuing their fortunes until dawn.

A small courtyard named after those who cheated at games of chance. Near Ponte dei Dai, authorities would sometimes apprehend barattieri (swindlers) who used loaded dice or other tricks to defraud fellow gamblers.

Named after the German mercenary soldiers who frequented this area. These Landsknechts were known for their love of gambling when off duty and would often gather near Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio for games of chance.

Named for the masks worn by gamblers seeking anonymity. In Venice, particularly near gambling hotspots like Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio, wealthy citizens and nobles would wear masks to conceal their identities while gambling.
A commercial street where gamblers would challenge each other to games of chance. Near Ponte dei Dai, this was where formal gambling challenges would be issued, often involving significant stakes.

Named after the card game that became popular among Venetian nobility. Though Ponte dei Dai was primarily known for dice games, this nearby street in Cannaregio hosted establishments where the card game of baccarat was played.

A paved street with a somewhat humorous name referring to those who lost at gambling. Many who crossed Ponte dei Dai full of hope would leave this way after losing their money at the nearby gaming establishments.

Named after the cloaks used for concealment. Gamblers near Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio often wore mantelli (cloaks) to hide their activities or to conceal their wealth and social status while engaged in games of chance.

A former canal filled in and named after 'bassetta,' a popular card game in Renaissance Venice. This game was played in establishments near Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio, attracting both noblemen and commoners.
Named after the noble Giustiniani family who owned properties in this part of Cannaregio. Members of this nobili family were known to frequent the gambling establishments near Ponte dei Dai.

Named after a gambling establishment where the house went bankrupt. Near Ponte dei Dai, this fondamenta commemorated a notable event where gamblers were so successful that they broke the bank of a local gaming house.

Named after the law enforcement officers who patrolled this area. Given the gambling activities around Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio, sbirri would regularly monitor the area to prevent violence and enforce regulations against illegal gambling.

A covered passageway possibly named after a Moorish merchant or resident. Venice had significant trade with North Africa, and some Moorish traders might have frequented the gambling establishments near Ponte dei Dai in Cannaregio.

Named as a counterpoint to the Street of the Losers, this calle celebrated the lucky few who walked away from the gambling areas near Ponte dei Dai as winners, perhaps becoming local legends in the process.
